title: Stanley Morison
content: **[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices): [Writers](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Writers): Stanley Morison** Temperamental typographical advisor to the [Monotype corporation](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Monotype%20corporation) and opinionated type historian and theoretician. Designer of [Times New Roman](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Times%20New%20Roman) which, along with [Helvetica](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Helvetica) and [Univers](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Univers), probably holds the honor of being the most well-known typeface of the [20th century](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/20th%20century). [Times New Roman](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Times%20New%20Roman) was his only type design, and the story of its development is told in [Walter Tracy](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Walter%20Tracy)'s Letters of Credit. His most well-known book is A Tally of Types, which is no longer an indispensable reference, but is still one of the most entertaining reads out there to the typographically inclined. Bibliography: ‘Towards An Ideal Type’, _[The Fleuron](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/The%20Fleuron)_ Number 2 (London: St. Stephen’s House, 1924) pp. 57-75 ‘Towards An Ideal Italic’, _[The Fleuron](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/The%20Fleuron)_ Number 5 (Cambridge: The University Press, 1926) pp. 93-129 ‘The Story of Gill Sans’, _[The Monotype Recorder](http://web.archive.org/web/20141102062738/http:/typophile.com/wiki/The%20Monotype%20Recorder)_ Volume 34, Number 4 (London: The Monotype Corporation Limited, Winter 1935-6) pp. i-viii
author: filip blazek
